audio.errorNoOggOpusSupportByApple: Your browser does not support OGG/Opus (taf) files at the moment. If you are using an Apple device, help us out by submitting a ticket to Apple for a fix!

community.discourse: The lively knowledge base for the project, a place to ask questions whose answers can be helpful for others.
community.getInvolvedText1: Be a part of our global contributor community by writing code, commenting on issues, or participate in discussons in our telegram group.
community.getInvolvedText2: Your best points of contact are the following locations
community.github: The place where all sources are stored for this and related projects. Where you can fork the repositories, contribute new or improved features, create issues or just give some feedback on already existing issues.
community.teddyCloudWiki: A Wiki contains, among other things, how to install TeddyCloud and how to solve possible problems.
community.telegram: The first level support if you need help or if you are interested in getting involved in the development of TeddyCloud.

contribution.communityValues2: Be respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences.
contribution.communityValues4: Foster what's best for the community.
contribution.communityValues5: Show empathy for other community members.
contribution.communityValues6: Decisions are made based on technical merit and consensus. The Teddycloud community aspires to treat everyone equally, and to value all contributions.
contribution.communityValuesExamples: Examples of behaviors that contribute to creating a positive environment include:
contribution.communityValuesIntro: In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, contributors and maintainers pledge to make participation in our project and our community a harassment-free experience for everyone - regardless of age, body size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
contribution.contributionIntro: The Teddycloud can only grow through the contributions of this community. Thanks so much for your enthusiasm and your work - we appreciate everything you do!
contribution.makeFirstContribution3: Answer questions on our telegram group.
contribution.makeFirstContribution4: Investigate bugs and issues on GitHub.
contribution.makeFirstContribution5: Review and comment on pull requests from other developers.
contribution.makeFirstContribution7: Give a "thumbs up" on issues that are relevant to you.
contribution.makeFirstContributionIntro: There are many ways to contribute to Teddycloud! You can contribute code and make improvements to the Teddycloud documentation. Our most common contributions include code, documentation, and community support.
contribution.title: Contribution

toniesJson.text: You are welcome to support us by sending us the missing data of the Tonies listed below. In the future this will be possible directly in TeddyCloud, at the moment you can use TeddyBench. Thank you in advance!

contributors.bigRoundOfApplause: A big round of applause for them!
contributors.contributorsIntro: This project relies on the tireless contributors who offer their free time and skills. Directly related to TeddyCloud are the contributors of the two projects teddycloud and teddycloud_web:
contributors.others: You can find more contributors to the entire topic complex in the other GitHub repositories at
contributors.supportTeamText: If you're enjoying TeddyCloud, consider supporting us with a sponsorship or tip!
contributors.teddyCloud: The most neccessary, but mostly invisible part of your TeddyCloud Server.
contributors.teddyCloudWeb: Which is actually this frontend you are using and seeing here.
contributors.title: Contributors

faq.intro: Here you can find answers to some frequently asked questions. If your question is not answered here, please visit the forum or use the Telegram group to get assistance.
faq.title: FAQ

supportRequestGuide.closing: Providing this level of detail will help the community resolve your issue more effectively. Thank you!

example.description: Below is an example of a well-structured support request to help you get started:
example.details:
Subject: Error Uploading File in TeddyCloud (Docker)

Description:
I encountered an error while trying to upload a file in TeddyCloud.

1. Actions performed:
- I logged in successfully.
- I went to the upload page and selected a file (testfile.pdf).
- I clicked the upload button.

2. Expected outcome:
- The file should upload successfully and appear in the file list.

3. Actual outcome:
- An error message appeared: 'Upload failed: Connection lost.'

4. Environment details:
- OS: Ubuntu 20.04
- Docker version: 24.0.2
- TeddyCloud version: 0.6.3

5. Logs:
Attached is the log extract (teddycloud_logs.txt) from the time the error occurred.
example.title: Example Support Request

supportRequestGuide.intro: When requesting support, providing detailed and clear information helps the community diagnose and resolve your issue faster. Follow these steps to ensure your support request includes all necessary details:

step1.content: Start with a concise summary of the issue. Mention any specific error messages you received (copy and paste the exact message if possible).
step1.title: Step 1: Clearly Describe the Problem

step2.intro: Describe in detail what you did leading up to the error. Include:
list: Actions performed (e.g., 'I logged in and tried to upload a file').
Expected outcome (e.g., 'The file should upload successfully').
Actual outcome (e.g., 'I got an error message: Upload failed').
step2.title: Step 2: Provide a Step-by-Step Description

list: Operating system and version (e.g., Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04).
Whether you're using Docker, and its version.
step3.title: Step 3: Include Technical Information

step4.intro: Provide logs to help diagnose the issue. Here's how:
list: Include the log output from the time the issue occurred.
Make sure to redact sensitive information before sharing.
step4.listFirstEntry: Run this command to collect logs:
step4.title: Step 4: Attach Relevant Logs

step5.content: If possible, include screenshots or a short screen recording to visually demonstrate the issue.
step5.title: Step 5: Screenshots or Videos (Optional)

step6.content: Let us know if you've already tried troubleshooting steps, such as restarting the service or checking the logs.
step6.title: Step 6: Steps You've Taken to Resolve the Issue

supportRequestGuide.title: How to Create a Good Support Request

translations.hint: If you see any bad translation, please come back to us on Telegram. French and Spanish are currently completely translated by ChatGPT.
translations.title: Translations

faq.answer: To force an update, perform a freshness check on your Toniebox. Press and hold one of the ears for approximately 3 seconds until you hear a sound. Wait until a second sound confirms the completion of the update.
faq.question: How can I force an update of a Tonie after assigning new content in TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Use the Audioencoder tool and add up to 99 audio files. Each file will be assigned its own track in the created TAF file.
faq.question: How can I create a multi-track TAF file?

faq.answer: You can add up to 16 Tonieboxes to a single TeddyCloud instance.
faq.question: How many Tonieboxes can I add to a TeddyCloud instance?

faq.answer: Place the tag on a connected Toniebox. It will automatically be added to your Tonies in TeddyCloud. If you have many unknown tags, you can filter for the last played tags or open the Toniebox management page and click on the last played tag.
faq.question: How can I add a new tag to TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: The easiest way to remove a tag is to hide it. Open the information modal for the tag you want to remove and click the 'Hide' button. The tag will remain hidden until it is placed on a Toniebox again. Alternatively, if you have access to the SD cards of all connected Tonieboxes, you can delete the tag physically by removing the corresponding content folder for that tag on each box and then removing it in TeddyCloud content view.
faq.question: How can I remove a tag from my TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Set up a separate content directory for each Toniebox in the Toniebox management settings. Afterward, the Tonies overview will feature a dropdown menu in the top right corner where you can choose between different content directories. You don't need to assign a unique content directory to each box; boxes with the same content directory will be grouped together in the Tonies overview.
faq.question: How can I manage different contents for a tag on different Tonieboxes?

faq.answer: Perform a freshness check on that Toniebox. This will re-add all tags that have ever been placed on the box (and are not deleted) to TeddyCloud. Original Tonies need to be placed at least once to get the cloud authentication and download their linked content to TeddyCloud.
faq.question: Why is the Tonies overview empty after adding a new content directory to a box?

faq.answer: Ensure that the 'nocloud' flag is set to true and verify that no one has secretly placed another tag on the box.
faq.question: Why does my tag with custom content always start from the beginning instead of the last played position?

faq.answer: Ensure the following settings are enabled: 'Cache Content' and 'Dump rUID/auth'. We also recommend enabling 'Cache to library'.
faq.question: Why isn't the content of my tags cached to TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Make sure you're using the correct type of tag. Only original NSP SLIX-L tags are generally compatible. You will find more information about this in the forum. If you have the CC3200 version of the Toniebox, you can enable other RFID tags as well. Check the wiki for more details. Additionally, ensure there is a certain distance between the tag and the Toniebox (at least 2-3mm) as a directly placed RFID tag won't work properly.
faq.question: Why isn't my RFID tag working?

fileBrowser.confirmDeleteDialog: Are you sure you want to delete {{fileToDelete}}?
fileBrowser.confirmMultipleDeleteDialog: Are you sure you want to delete the selected rows?

encodeFiles.encodeFiles: Encode selected files into a taf file. Only the following file types will be considered:
encodeFiles.noSupportedFiletypesChoosen: No supported file types chosen. The following file types are supported:

deleteFileFolder.text: Deletes the file or folder (only if the folder is empty). Note: If this file is assigned to a Tonie/Tag, the reference will not be updated.
deleteFileFolder.title: Delete File/Folder

duplicateTAPFile.text: Creates a duplicate of the selected TAP file.
duplicateTAPFile.title: Duplicate TAP File

editTAFMetadata.text: Opens the metadata editor to modify TAF file details. Changes are stored in tonies.custom.json. (WIP)
editTAFMetadata.title: Edit TAF Metadata

editTAPPlaylist.text: Opens the Tonie Audio Playlist Editor to manage TAP files. (WIP)
editTAPPlaylist.title: Edit TAP Playlist

migrateToAudioIdFolder.text: Moves the TAF file into the library's 'by/audioId' folder and updates the source in the JSON file.
migrateToAudioIdFolder.title: Migrate TAF File to Library by AudioId

migrateToLibraryRoot.text: Moves the TAF file to the library's root folder and updates the source in the corresponding JSON file.
migrateToLibraryRoot.title: Migrate TAF File to Library Root

moveFile.text: Move the file to a new location. Note: If this file is assigned to a Tonie/Tag, the reference will not be updated.
moveFile.title: Move File

playAudioFile.text: Opens the audio player and starts playback of the file.
playAudioFile.title: Play Audio File

renameFile.text: Renames the file. Note: If this file is assigned to a Tonie/Tag, the reference will not be updated automatically.
renameFile.title: Rename File

deleteSelectedFiles.text: Delete the selected files or folders (only if empty). Note: References to deleted files in any Tonie/Tag will not be updated.
deleteSelectedFiles.title: Delete Selected Files/Folders

encodeFilesToTAF.text: Add supported files to an encoder queue. You can select multiple files to encode them into a TAF file, which can then be assigned to a Tonie/Tag.
encodeFilesToTAF.title: Encode Files to TAF

moveSelectedFiles.text: Move the selected files to a new location. Note: References to these files in any Tonie/Tag will not be updated. Selected folders will be skipped.
moveSelectedFiles.title: Move Selected Files

multiSelection.text: To perform actions on multiple files, select their checkboxes. New action icons will appear in the header, allowing you to move, delete, or encode multiple files:
multiSelection.title: Multi-Selection Actions

openDirectory.text: Double-click on a directory to open it. Directories have a folder icon in front and show <DIR> as their size.
openDirectory.title: Open Directory

openTAFViewer.text: Double-click on a TAF file to view its header. The TAF Header Viewer shows details like AudioId, SHA1 hash, and file size. AudioId and SHA1 hash are required for entries in tonies.custom.json.
openTAFViewer.title: Open TAF Header Viewer

openTAPJSONViewer.text: Double-click on a TAP or JSON file to open the JSON Viewer.
openTAPJSONViewer.title: Open TAP/JSON Viewer

viewTonieInfoModal.text: Click on the image of a Tonie/Tag in the row to open the TonieInfo modal. This displays detailed information, including a larger image and tracklist (if available).
viewTonieInfoModal.title: View TonieInfo Modal

features.description: TeddyCloud is an alternative server for your Toniebox, allowing you to host the cloud services locally. This gives you the control about which data is sent to the original manufacturer's cloud and allows you to host your own figurine audio files on e.g. your NAS or any other server.

items.01provideAudioContent: provide audio content over the air
items.05convertAudio: on-the-fly convert audio streams via ffmpeg for webradio and streams
items.06definePlaylists: define tonie audio playlists (PoC in WebFrontend)
items.08filterTags: filter custom tags to prevent deletion

items.01assignContent: assign content and other properties to each tag
items.02searchStreams: search and assign webradio streams to each tag
items.03defineMetaData: define meta data of your custom tags (PoC in WebFrontend)

features.05managePlaylists: Manage your Tonie Audio Playlist library (PoC in WebFrontend)
features.06convertAudioFile: Convert any audio file to a tonie audio file

items.01singleBoxManagement: single box management, manage all as one, group boxes for management as you like
items.02cloudAccess: disable/enable cloud access and other cloud related properties
items.03maxVolume: configure maximum volume for speaker and headphones
items.06customizeSounds: customize original box sounds (ex. jingle) over the air

items.01certificates: extract/inject certificates on a esp32 firmware dump
items.04extractCertificates: extract certificates and store in TeddyCloud
items.05guidelineLegacyMethod: guideline for flashing with the legacy method (no GUI, only command line)

items.02AltUrlCustomPatch: form based generation of the AltUrl.custom.305 Patch

items.01Guideline: detailed guideline for the flashing process

futureFeatures.05completeCustomToniesIntegration: Completion of Custom Tonies Json WebFront Integration ("Meta data of custom tags")
futureFeatures.06moreStats: More stats about your played Tonies/Tags
futureFeatures.07securityImprovements: Security improvements like Access control (tonieboxes and user)

features.title: Features TeddyCloud

availableBoxModal.cc3200Hint: , that you are booting the correct firmware slot, that all necessary patches are set
availableBoxModal.newBoxAvailable: Please check if the new box appears in the table below. If it is not listed, something may have gone wrong. Ensure you have enabled the setting "Add new boxes", the box is visible in your Wi-Fi, that the replacement CA has been flashed{{cc3200Hint}} and that the correct IP/URL for TeddyCloud is being used. If the box still does not appear, check here:

adguard.adGuardRequirement: AdGuard: Make sure AdGuard Home is installed and configured on a device in your network.
adguard.clientExplanation: Limits this rule to requests coming specifically from the IP address YYY.YYY.YYY.YYY (Toniebox IP).
adguard.dnsRewriteExplanation: Specifies that the DNS response should be a successful (NOERROR) A record pointing to XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX (TeddyCloud IP).
adguard.ipReservationInstructions: IP Address Reservations: Ensure that both your TeddyCloud instance and Toniebox have static IPs on the network, either by assigning them manually or using DHCP reservations in your router settings.
adguard.loggingMonitoringInstructions: Logging and Monitoring: In AdGuard Home, enable query logging to monitor and confirm that the Toniebox requests are resolved correctly.
adguard.setupInstructionsTitle: To set up AdGuard as your DNS server with custom DNS rewrite rules for your TeddyCloud instance and Toniebox, follow these steps:
adguard.step1Instructions: Log into your AdGuard Home dashboard. Go to Settings > General Settings. Under DNS settings, enable AdGuard as the primary DNS resolver by setting it as the DNS server on your network/router or for individual devices.
adguard.step1Title: 1. Set Up AdGuard Home as Your DNS Server
adguard.step2Instructions: In the AdGuard Home dashboard, navigate to Filters > Custom Filtering Rules. Add the following custom rules to rewrite DNS queries for specific domains to your TeddyCloud IP, only when requested by the Toniebox.
adguard.step3Instructions: Restart the AdGuard Home service to apply changes. Test the DNS rewrites to confirm that requests from your Toniebox to prod.de.tbs.toys and rtnl.bxcl.de resolve to your TeddyCloud IP. Other devices on the network should resolve these domains using the regular DNS resolution (unless specified otherwise).
adguard.teddyCloudIp: TeddyCloud IP: Obtain the static IP address of your TeddyCloud instance (replace XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX).
adguard.tonieboxIp: Toniebox IP: Find the static IP address of your Toniebox (replace YYY.YYY.YYY.YYY).

boxFlashingCommon.certificatesIntro: On first run teddyCloud will generate the CA and certificates with the starting date 2015-11-03. Those will be placed in /certs/server/. This also generates the replacement CA for the toniebox certs/server/ca.der.
boxFlashingCommon.dnsBewareText: This will cut off the connection of all tonieboxes within your network, which arn`t patched with your replacement CA!
boxFlashingCommon.dnsText1: Set the DNS entries for prod.de.tbs.toys and rtnl.bxcl.de to the teddyCloud servers ip-address.
boxFlashingCommon.dumpCertificatesIntro1: You`ll need the flash:/cert/ca.der (Boxine CA), flash:/cert/client.der (Client Cert) and flash:/cert/private.der (Client private key).
boxFlashingCommon.dumpCertificatesIntro2: Keep a backup of the certificates, especially the client.der and private.der. Without it you won`t be able to connect to the cloud anymore!

openWrt.dnsText2: As an alternative you can set the gateway for the tonieboxes to the ip of teddyCloud. With OpenWRT it works this way:

UARTHint.description: Please double-check if your UART supports both 3.3V and 5V. In this case, you should find a jumper on the board to select the correct mode. You can see examples of such jumpers here (but there are others):
UARTHint.title: Important
UARTHint.warning: In any case, make absolutely sure that 3.3V (often labelled 3v3) is set! If you are using the 5V setting, there is a high risk that you will break your Toniebox!

boxSetup.boxSetupIntro1: This page provides a complete overview of the steps required to add your Toniebox to TeddyCloud. If you encounter any issues, feel free to visit the

boxVersion.cc3200con1: This is the oldest version available
boxVersion.cc3200pro1: Flashing via command line + UART adapter
boxVersion.cc3200pro3: Easily switch between different firmware versions (up to 9 slots, including the original firmware) when custom bootloader is installed
boxVersion.cc3200pro4: Patches allow changes to TeddyCloud IP/hostname when custom bootloader is installed
boxVersion.cc3200pro5: Additional patches available including support of non-SLIX-L NFC tags when using the custom bootloader
boxVersion.cc3235con1: Flashing is challenging and requires direct memory access
boxVersion.cc3235con3: CA replacement can be unreliable, often needing multiple attempts
boxVersion.countryOfManufactureText: Check the bottom of the box to see if it was made in China or Hungary. Tonieboxes manufactured in China (from 01/2024 onward) are likely to be ESP32-based.
boxVersion.esp32con1: Custom firmware is under development but is currently on hold and not functional in its present state
boxVersion.esp32con2: Changes to TeddyCloud IP/hostname or switching back to original firmware require re-flashing
boxVersion.esp32pro2: Easiest flashing method via browser + UART adapter
boxVersion.esp32pro3: ESP32 supported by a large developer community
boxVersion.howToIdentify: How to identify your Toniebox version without opening the package
boxVersion.howToIdentifyIntro: Since there is no label specifying the exact version, identifying the Toniebox version requires some minor hints:
boxVersion.intro: Currently, there are four known versions of the Toniebox, which mainly differ by the MCU (Microcontroller Unit) they use:
boxVersion.macAddressCheckText: The most reliable way to determine the version is by checking for a printed MAC address, which may be on the package or directly on the Toniebox. Use macvendors.com to look up the MAC address and find out the vendor of the MCU, which can help you identify the Toniebox version.
boxVersion.title: About the different Toniebox versions
boxVersion.whatVersion: What version of Toniebox should I get?
boxVersion.whatVersionConclusion: We do not recommend the V3 CC3235 version due to the difficulties in flashing and limited support. Currently, the V1/V2 (TI CC3200) version offers the most features, including custom bootloader and firmware support. However, for future-proofing, the ESP32-based V4 version is our top recommendation.
boxVersion.whatVersionIntro: If you haven't yet chosen a Toniebox, here are the pros and cons of each version to help you decide. Ultimately, the choice depends on your specific needs and preferences. At least all versions are compatible with TeddyCloud.

boxSetup.flashBoxText: To add your Toniebox to TeddyCloud, some modifications are required. Depending on your Toniebox version, there are three specific guidelines to follow:
boxSetup.identifyTonieboxVersionText: The first step in adding your Toniebox to TeddyCloud is identifying its version. The version determines the specific method needed to modify your Toniebox to make it compatible with TeddyCloud.

identifyVersion.boxMacTooLong: The entered MAC-Address is invalid (too long)
identifyVersion.boxVersion: This means your Box is a
identifyVersion.cc3200text: This version has the text CC3200R1 on the main chip as shown in the following pictures.
identifyVersion.cc3235text: Here you will also find the version on the main chip as shown in the following pictures namely CC3235.
identifyVersion.errorMac: Could not identify vendor with the given MAC-Address
identifyVersion.esp32text: The PCB and main chip of the ESP32 version looks like the following pictures.
identifyVersion.generalInstruction1: If you're unable to retrieve the MAC address, you can identify the specific version of your Toniebox by
identifyVersion.generalInstruction2: it and checking the main chip on the PCB for identification. Click on the tab for each version to get more details of them.
identifyVersion.identifyUsingMac: Identify your version with your Tonieboxes MAC-Address. You find the MAC-Address on the bottom of your Toniebox.
identifyVersion.proceedToFlash1: Proceed to the flashing page for the selected version:
identifyVersion.tiInstruction: To find out the specific version, you have to open your Toniebox and use the main chip of the PCB for identification.
identifyVersion.title: Identify your Toniebox version
identifyVersion.vendor: The vendor of your Toniebox main chip is

boxSetup.newbieGuides: There are several 'Newbie' guides available in the Revvox Forum. You may want to check them out as well:

openBoxGuide.alternativeGuidelineVideo: Alternativly you can watch the following guide in Youtube:
openBoxGuide.finally: Now you can access the PCB to identify your Toniebox version and modify your Toniebox!
openBoxGuide.guideSourcePart1: Step 1-4 of this guide is taken from
openBoxGuide.guideSourcePart4: who is also the creator of all images used. This guideline is licensed under the
openBoxGuide.step1Text1: Put the Toniebox on a flat surface (e.g. a desk or a workbench).
openBoxGuide.step1Text2: Apply some pressure and turn the Toniebox counterclockwise to unlock the two clips beneath the bottom plate.
openBoxGuide.step1Text3: You will hear a "klick" when the two clips unlock.
openBoxGuide.step3Text: Remove the Phillips #1 screw on the bottom of the Toniebox.
openBoxGuide.step4Text: Lift the inner part out of the foam housing.
openBoxGuide.step5Text1: The battery pack and motherboard are secured with just two standard Phillips screws.
openBoxGuide.step5Text2: Remove the screws, and you can detach the battery pack from the PCB.
openBoxGuide.title: How to Open and Access Your Toniebox PCB

boxSetup.setupTeddyCloudText: Congratulations! By reaching this page, you've successfully set up TeddyCloud!
boxSetup.title: Add your Toniebox to TeddyCloud
boxSetup.uploadCertificateIntro: You should upload the extracted certificates to TeddyCloud if this is your first Toniebox or if you want to designate this Toniebox as the one used to download content from the original Tonies cloud. Additionally, you need to add the certificates to the Toniebox within TeddyCloud. To do this, navigate to the Tonieboxes section, click on the Certificate icon, and upload the certificates again.
boxSetup.uploadCertificatesToBox: If your Toniebox is displayed, navigate to the Tonieboxes section and upload the certificates extracted during the previous certificate step to the newly added box. Use the certificate icon in the card footer of the box to complete the upload:
boxSetup.useItText: Now you can assign custom content to your Tonies or custom tags, sit back, and enjoy the endless possibilities of your unlocked Toniebox!

tonieboxes.boxWithoutAPIAccess: Toniebox with no TeddyCloud API access!
tonieboxes.boxWithoutAPIAccessGoToTonieboxes: If you want to change that, enable API access for the mentioned
tonieboxes.boxWithoutAPIAccessText: The following Tonieboxes do not have API access enabled:

applyingPatchesSection.finish: If you have modified the ngCfg.json as instructed, please reassemble your Toniebox and power it on. Do a freschnessccheck, wait a moment, then click 'Show available boxes' to display the available Tonieboxes in your TeddyCloud.
applyingPatchesSection.introduction: The configuration of the custom Bootloader is done within the configuration file ngCfg.json located on your Toniebox SD card in directory sd://revvox/boot (you should have already placed all hackiebox NG bootloader files on your Toniebox SD card in step 2).
applyingPatchesSection.section2_part1: If you want to use your Toniebox with Teddycloud we recommend using the second firmware slot. So set in the general configuration section the element "activeImg" to "ofw2".
applyingPatchesSection.section2_part2: If you have created the "altUrl.custom.305"-patch, you should copy the patch file onto your Toniebox SD card to sd://revvox/boot/patch. After that you can add the patch in the configuration section of the second firmware slot ("ofw2"). Be aware, that only one altUrl-Patch is applied. Please remove "altUrl.tc.fritz.box" and/or "altUrl.305" if they are present in the configuration.

technicalDetailsCollapse.activeImgDesc: Sets the firmware slot to select at startup
technicalDetailsCollapse.bootFlashImgDesc: Read firmware from file on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.collapseTitle: Technical details of the configuration file
technicalDetailsCollapse.firmwareSectionIntro: There are nine firmware slots, named ofw1, ofw2, ofw3, cfw1, cfw2, cfw3, add1, add2 and add3.
technicalDetailsCollapse.flashImgDesc: Path to the file on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.hashFileDesc: Check hash from ng-XXX?.sha file (true) or from the last 64 byte of the firmware itself (ofw)
technicalDetailsCollapse.minBatteryLevelDesc: Poweroff voltage to protect the battery. Divide through 2785 to get voltage (Standard 3.18V)
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixDesc: Add magic bytes to the firmware image to make ofw directly boot
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixFlashDesc: Magic bytes read from the ofw bootloader on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixValueDesc: Magic bytes to be placed into the OFW Image during boot (can be extracted from OFW BL data[-8:-4])
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwSimBLDesc: Read image to boot from flash:/sys/mcubootinfo.bin and load the image from flash:/sys/mcuimgN.bin instead of reading from sd (like the ofw bootloader)
technicalDetailsCollapse.patchesDesc: List of patches to load, see:
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part1: The configuration for the bootloader is saved within
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part2: . All sections or keys starting with an underscore "_" are comments and will be ignored.
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part3: The configuration file consists of a general section and dedicated sections for the 9 available firmware slots.
technicalDetailsCollapse.serialLogDesc: Enable log to UART (TX) @921600 baud. Only works for debug build!
technicalDetailsCollapse.title: Configuration
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitForBootDesc: Waits for an earpress on before firmware boot with a blink sequence (blue, green, cyan, black)
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitForPressDesc: Waits for an earpress on startup with a blink sequence (blue, green, cyan, black)
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitTimeoutInSDesc: Timeout in seconds for waitForPress if no earpress (hibernation)
technicalDetailsCollapse.watchdogDesc: Keep watchdog enabled when booting firmware (if booting fails, box will restart)

certificates.alreadyAvailable: The certificates ca.der, client.der and private.der should be already available in:
certificates.extractAgain: If not, ensure you have done step 2 correctly. You can also extract the files from the box using the cc3200 tool once more (your PC should still be connected via UART and debug port to the Toniebox)

cc3200BoxFlashing.certificatesDumpedCAreplacementFlashed: Certificates dumped and CA replacement flashed
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxConnectDebugPortText1: You can use a dedicated Tag Connector like
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxConnectDebugPortText2: or alternatively use thin wires for the connection.
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxConnectTableIntro: Next, connect the Toniebox debug port to the UART as described in the following table:
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxIntro: You need to connect your UART to the Debug Port. Start by locating the debug port on the unpopulated side of the PCB, which is on the bottom. The layout of the debug port is shown in the following image.
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxProceed: You are now ready to proceed!
cc3200BoxFlashing.connectToTonieboxText: Ensure that the UART is configured to 3.3V before connecting the UART programmer to your computer via USB. The green LED on the Toniebox mainboard should stay steadily lit (no flashing or blinking). If it does not, your connections might be loose or incorrect. Disconnect the programmer, double-check all connections, and try again. If you are working with thin wires, consider applying hot glue to secure them in place and prevent any movement. Additionally, ensure that the Toniebox is powered using its charger.
cc3200BoxFlashing.customUrlPatchHint: Please create this patch only if the existing altUrl.305.json and altUrl.tc.fritz.box.json patches are not functioning with your current TeddyCloud setup. If they do meet your needs you can proceed by clicking 'Next'.
cc3200BoxFlashing.dumpCertificatesLink: Find instructions for dumping certificates here
cc3200BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementIntro: It is recommended to flash the replacement CA to /cert/c2.der and use the Hackiebox-NG bootloader with the altCA.305 patch (more details provided in the next steps). This setup enables you to switch seamlessly between the original certificate and your replacement certificate.
cc3200BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementOutro: Ensure that you have selected the correct path to the ca.der file.
cc3200BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementText: To write the downloaded c2.der file (refer to the steps above) to your Toniebox, use the following command:
cc3200BoxFlashing.hint: There is currently no direct support of flashing your CC3200 Toniebox with TeddyCloud, but you will find a step by step guidance here:
cc3200BoxFlashing.hint2: Please follow then the CC3200 path:
cc3200BoxFlashing.hintPatchHost: Enter the hostname of your TeddyCloud instance and then click 'Create altUrl.custom.305.patch'. The patch will automatically download afterwards.
cc3200BoxFlashing.hostnameTooLong: The hostname must not exceed 12 characters.

installingBootloader.downloadText2: . Please unzip the release to your desired working directory. You will find a directory called flash there for the file(s) that need to be copied to the flash and a directory called sd for the sd files.

existingInstallation.backupText: To verify that you have currently installed the ofw bootloader to /sys/pre-img.bin you may download the file from flash:
existingInstallation.intro: You may use the (old) Hackiebox CFW to upload the preloader. This way you can install it over the air without direct access to the flash if you have already installed a previous version of the cfw bootloader/preloader. Just run the Hackiebox CFW and use the webinterface to upload the new /sys/mcuimg.bin.
existingInstallation.outro: To verify that the upload was successful you can download the mcuimg.bin from flash afterwards and compare it with the flash/sys/mcuimg.bin you have just uploaded.
existingInstallation.title: Stage 1b: Preloader, updating existing installation

firstInstallation.installPreloaderText1: Please ensure that you have backed up the original firmware in a safe location. Double check that you have the original mcuimg.bin stored somewhere safe. If everything is fine, then install the preloader with the following command
firstInstallation.installPreloaderText2: You've installed the Preloader onto the Toniebox. Please continue with Stage 2: Installing the bootloader onto the SD card.
firstInstallation.moveOriginalText1: First of all you need to copy your just backuped original mcuimg.bin (original bootloader) from your toniebox to a different location (flash:/sys/pre-img.bin) to boot it with the HackieboxNG Bootloader later on. Please don't confuse the mcuimg.bin (ofw bootloader) you are going to dump with the mcuimg.bin within the hackiebox zip package. (/flash/sys/mcuimg.bin)
firstInstallation.moveOriginalText2: We already made a full backup so we can find mcuimg.bin under /currentDir/ExtractedFromBox/sys/mcuimg.bin since you should still be running cc3200tool from that directory write the file to the toniebox:
firstInstallation.title: Stage 1a: Preloader, first time installation

importantTBFiles.caDer: Contains the Certificate Authority to check the https connection for the API
importantTBFiles.clientDer: Public key of the box, don't share
importantTBFiles.mcuBootInfo: Decides which firmware slot to boot
importantTBFiles.privateDer: Private key of the box, don't share; it is used to authenticate against the original cloud

installingBootloader.inCaseText: In case that there are some files that do not exist on the box, the command may exit with an error and thus never will properly create the backup.bin, split the command into two:

installingBootloaderStage2.intro: Copy over all the contents of the sd folder to the sd card of the toniebox. Copy over the original bootloader (mcuimg.bin from your backup) to the first ofw slot sd:/revvox/boot/ng-ofw1.bin. Now the HackieboxNG bootloader will instantly boot the original bootloader and run the original firmware.
installingBootloaderStage2.text1: Note: The preloader will load any file placed to sd:/revvox/boot/ngbootloader.bin.
installingBootloaderStage2.text2: More about the different firmware slots and the configuration

installingBootloader.intro: Before installing the Hackiebox NG Bootloader, please make a full file based + flash backup of your toniebox's flash with cc3200tool. We use COM3 as example port, but you may use a different COM port or the right device on linux ex. /dev/ttyUSB0.

preface.intro: Installing the new bootloader is split into two stages and differs whether it's a first install or and update to an existing installation:
preface.title: Preface

installingBootloader.resetCommand: If your UART programmer has a DTR pin, use `--reset dtr` before each command (e.g., `cc3200tool -p COM3 --reset dtr ...`). Otherwise, you'll need to briefly connect the RTS pin to GND before each command. If you skip this step, the console will display "timed out while waiting for ack" and abort the operation.
installingBootloader.verifyBackup: Ensure the backup.bin is a way bigger than 0 kb. Please check if the dump and the dumped files contain all important Toniebox files:

cc3200BoxFlashing.linkGeneral: Patching your Toniebox for using with TeddyCloud
cc3200BoxFlashing.title: CC3200 Box Flashing
cc3200BoxFlashing.usingThinWiresAsTagConnector: Thin wires used as a connector

CH341AProgrammer.CH341Sop8remove: Trim here until it fits properly.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText1: Connect the clamp to the IS25LP032D Flash memory. Ensure the red cable on the clamp aligns with the dot on the chip marking pin 1.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText2: If the clamp does not hold, it may be colliding with a nearby black block. Trim more plastic if needed. Do not connect the CH341A yet. Double-check cable positions.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText3: When ready, plug the CH341A into the USB port on your computer. The Toniebox light should turn solid green. If it flickers, the clamp may not be positioned well. Disconnect the CH341A, adjust the clamp, and try again to ensure a good connection.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText4: Once the LED is steady green, the connection is good. Open a terminal on your computer and type the following commands:
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText5: Repeat this process at least three times.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText6: After three reads, compare all dumps to confirm consistency.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText7: Once you confirm that all versions are consistent, proceed with certificate extraction.
CH341AProgrammer.flashMemoryDumpText8: Remove the CH341A from the USB port and remove the clamp to avoid potential shorts or issues if the clamp accidentally moves.
CH341AProgrammer.prep1: Obtain a CH341A programmer (only purchase the black version with a gold line and rounded edges).
CH341AProgrammer.prep2: Trim the plastic on the CH341A clamp if necessary, so it can fit onto the IS25LP032D Flash memory.
CH341AProgrammer.prep3: Ensure both the PCB and the battery are disconnected.
CH341AProgrammer.prep4: Connect the CH341A to the computer and confirm it is recognized. You can do this as follows:
CH341AProgrammer.prepConclusions1: If the output differs, the small bridge between pins 1 and 2 on the CH341A may not be set. Once confirmed, unplug the CH341A from the USB port. This check ensures everything is connected correctly.
CH341AProgrammer.prepConclusions2: Make sure the SOP8 module in the CH341A kit and the clamp are connected as shown in the picture.
CH341AProgrammer.prepConclusions3: Only when preparations are complete can we proceed with the extraction process.
CH341AProgrammer.preparation: Only required if you plan to perform the flashing with a CH341A Programmer
CH341AProgrammer.readingFlash: Reading Flash with the CH341A Programmer
CH341AProgrammer.writingFlash: Writing Flash with the CH341A Programmer

cc3235BoxFlashing.certificatesDumpedCAreplacementFlashed: Certificates dumped and CA replacement flashed
cc3235BoxFlashing.dnsBewareText: This will cut off the connection of all tonieboxes within your network, which arn`t patched with your replacement CA!
cc3235BoxFlashing.dnsLink: Find instructions for adapting DNS here
cc3235BoxFlashing.dnsText1: Set the DNS entries for prod.de.tbs.toys and rtnl.bxcl.de to the teddyCloud servers ip-address.
cc3235BoxFlashing.dnsText2: As an alternative you can set the gateway for the tonieboxes to the ip of teddyCloud. With OpenWRT it works this way:
cc3235BoxFlashing.dumpCertificatesCC3235: You`ll have to manually extract it from the flash of the box with a SOP8 clamp directly from the memory or by desoldering it. Reading in-circuit can be tricky, but is possible. We recommend flashrom as tool for that. It may be necessary to use a more recent version of it.
cc3235BoxFlashing.dumpCertificatesLink: Find instructions for dumping certificates here
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAReplacementDescription1: Unfortunately, the CA certificate generated by TeddyCloud during its initial setup can sometimes cause a BAD_CERTIFICATE error when connecting a CC3235 Toniebox to TeddyCloud. To resolve this issue, try generating the certificate manually using the legacy
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAReplacementDescription2: script with faketime installed. Copy the generated files to the certs/server directory within the TeddyCloud installation folder.
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAReplacementDescription3: Please note that new server certificates, including the newly generated CA certificate, may disrupt connections with any already connected Tonieboxes. To ensure uninterrupted service, please update the CA replacement file on all your Tonieboxes with the newly generated certificate.
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAReplacementTitle: Attention: TeddyCloud CA Certificate Compatibility Issues
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementText1: Replace the original CA within your flash dump with the replacement CA and reflash it to your box.
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementText2: If the box does not connect at all (codeword owl), you may try the old gencerts.sh to generate new certificates and reflash the box.
cc3235BoxFlashing.flashCAreplacementText3: Attention: The ca.der file referenced in the code snippet must be the TeddyCloud Replacement CA!

flashCollapse.cc3235flashWithSMDGrippers: Flash memory with connected SMD grippers
flashCollapse.collapseTitle: Help: IS25LP032D Flash memory on CC3235
flashCollapse.sop8Clamp: Flash memory with connected SOP8 clamp

cc3235BoxFlashing.hint: There is currently no direct support of flashing your CC3235 Toniebox with TeddyCloud, but you will find a step by step guidance here:
cc3235BoxFlashing.hint2: Please follow then the CC3235 path:
cc3235BoxFlashing.hwToolSpecificText: Depending on the hardware you plan to use for flashing your Toniebox, additional preparations are required. Please select the option you will follow:
cc3235BoxFlashing.installflashromtoolLink: Visit the tool's homepage for more information
cc3235BoxFlashing.installflashromtoolText: Make sure the computer you're using for flashing has flashrom installed. If not, install it using the following commands:
cc3235BoxFlashing.linkGeneral: Patching your Toniebox for using with TeddyCloud
cc3235BoxFlashing.locateFlashMemoryText: Identify the IS25LP032D flash memory chip on the board; it is located to the right of the charging dock.

pico.preparation: Only required if you plan to perform the flashing with a Raspberry Pi Pico
pico.readingFlash: Reading Flash with Raspberry Pi Pico
pico.readingFlashText1: As a probe, you may use a Raspberry Pi Pico with firmware that supports the serprog protocol.
pico.readingFlashText2: It's recommended to perform multiple reads and compare results.
pico.writingFlash: Writing Flash with Raspberry Pi Pico

cc3235BoxFlashing.preparationText: Please connect your Toniebox to your Wi-Fi and update its firmware. Many boxes are shipped with a production firmware that needs to be updated. Otherwise the box won`t work as it should. It is not necessary to connect the box to the mytonies app/account.
cc3235BoxFlashing.preparationTextLink: Connect the box without the setup assistant.
cc3235BoxFlashing.title: CC3235 Box Flashing
cc3235BoxFlashing.useCC3200ToolToExtract: You can use the cc3200tool to extract your certificates from the flash dump afterwards.

tonieboxes.confirmDeleteDialog: Do you really want to delete {{tonieboxToDelete}}?

connectESP32Modal.connectESP32Text1: Please connect the jumper J100 (Boot) and reset the box to put it into the required UARTmode. Connect your 3.3V UART to J103 (Toniebox J103 [TxD | RxD | GND] -> UART: TxD -> RxD, RxD -> TxD, GND -> GND).
connectESP32Modal.connectESP32Text2: If you`re unsure in which mode the ESP32 is starting, check the following.
connectESP32Modal.downloadModeText: LED is off, no sound, Serial output:
connectESP32Modal.esp32UartJ103Clamp4PinHint: If you have only 4-pin clamp instead of the needed 3-pin clamp (as shown above), so it`s not aligned perfectlys. Try to place the pins as centrally as possible on the contacts.
connectESP32Modal.esp32UartJ103ClampTitle: Connect UART to ESP32 J103 using a clamp
connectESP32Modal.normalModeText: LED blinking green, startup sound is played, Serial output:
connectESP32Modal.warningText: If the serial monitor is open it will block esptool.py from accessing the esp. If you get a BROWNOUT_RST check your power supply / battery. SPI_FAST_FLASH_BOOT indicates a boot without the J100 jumper.

editModelModal.name: Name
editModelModal.placeholderSearchForAModel: Select color variant of your Toniebox
editModelModal.successOnModelChangeDetails: New model "{{model}}"of the Toniebox {{mac}} was saved sucessfully.
editModelModal.successOnNameChangeDetails: New name "{{name}}"of the Toniebox {{mac}} was saved sucessfully.

esp32BoxFlashing.adaptBaudrateOnProblemsText: If the progress freezes or gets stuck while reading or writing flash memory, try adjusting the baud rate using the select field "Baudrate" at the top.
esp32BoxFlashing.baudRateInfo: If you encounter issues reading or writing to the flash, try changing the baud rate. The default is 921600.
esp32BoxFlashing.browserNotSupported: The integrated ESP32 Box flashing functionality can only be used with browsers that support the Web Serial API. Unfortunately, your current browser does not support this feature. Please use a browser that supports the Web Serial API, such as Chrome or Edge.

esp32flasher.confirmFlashDialog: Do you really want to flash your Toniebox? Please ensure a stable connection and do not interrupt the process!
esp32flasher.confirmFlashDialogHint: To ensure your Toniebox works correctly, the specified TeddyCloud instance is absolutely necessary. If your TeddyCloud is offline, your Toniebox won't be able to access new content!
esp32flasher.downloadFlashFilesHint: The firmware images are stored in your server's data directory in case you want to reflash them. In case you want to save your firmware images somewhere else, you can download them and move them to a safe place:
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesAutomaticallyHint: Click the button "Extract certificates for TeddyCloud" to automatically extract and store the certificates in TeddyCloud.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesAutomaticallyHint2: Certificates will be stored in up to two locations: first, in the base client certificate directory ../{{certDir}}/ for TeddyCloud (if no certificates are already present), and second, in the folder ../{{certDir}}/{{mac}}.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHint: You can also extract the certificates manually by following the steps below.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP1: You can either do that with the teddycloud executable on your computer or you may do it via the docker shell
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP2: Please check the filename of the extracted certs, especially the case! Change them to lowercase if they are uppercase.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP3: For your first Toniebox setup with TeddyCloud, copy the certificates into the base client certificates directory. TeddyCloud uses these certificates to authenticate with the official Tonies Cloud, allowing content to be downloaded without Toniebox interaction (e.g., when you click 'Download' on a Tonie in the GUI).
esp32flasher.extractingCertificates409ResponseForceOv: The initial attempt to store certificates failed: {{error}}. Would you like to overwrite the existing files?
esp32flasher.extractingCertificatesSuccessfulDetails: Certificates successfully extracted from "{{file}}" and stored in TeddyCloud.
esp32flasher.flagPreviousHostname: Flash image contains a previous set hostname of TeddyCloud (WIP, not processed currently)
esp32flasher.hintESP32FirmwareFlashed: The patching should be done. Please disconnect the Toniebox from the UART, remove the short circuit from J100 and restart the box. It should now be able to connect to TeddyCloud!
esp32flasher.hintESP32FirmwareReseted: The reset should be done. Please disconnect the Toniebox from the UART, remove the short circuit from J100 and restart the box. It should be no longer connected to your Teddycloud. Do a freschnessccheck to test if it works fine.
esp32flasher.hintFlashESP32: Disconnect the powersource of your Toniebox once more. Click on "Flash ESP32", if necessary choose the COM-Port. Then connect your Toniebox to power and wait till the step is done!
esp32flasher.hintPatchFlash: To apply the selected/read flash with your TeddyCloud CA certificate and possibly make other adjustments like the TeddyCloud hostname and/or WiFi credentials, click 'Patch' after entering the information or proceed to the next step without patching.
esp32flasher.hintPatchHost: Enter the desired hostname for your TeddyCloud instance.
esp32flasher.hintPatchWifi: Optionally enter the WiFi credentials for your Toniebox.
esp32flasher.hintReadESP32ImportFlash: Now disconnect the powersource of your Toniebox. Make sure that the UART operates in 3.3V mode. Connect your UART with your PC and Toniebox. Short cut the J100 pinholes. Click on "Read Flash" or "Load File", then choose the COM-Port. Then connect your Toniebox to power and wait till the step is done!
esp32flasher.hostnameTooLong: The hostname should be less than 13 characters long.
esp32flasher.noPortAvailable: No port available or user aborted
esp32flasher.patchingSuccessful: Patching successful, ready to flash {{size}} MiB.
esp32flasher.portOpenFailedInUse: Failed to open this port. Already in use?
esp32flasher.resetBoxineTooltip: To reset your Toniebox to its original firmware, press this button to begin the process. You will need to select the original backup of the firmware, which will then be flashed onto your Toniebox in its untouched state. Unfortunately, if you do not have a backup of the original firmware, it will not be possible to reset your Toniebox.
esp32flasher.wifiCredentialsIncomplete: WiFi credentials incomplete! Please enter both SSID AND password, or leave both fields empty!

esp32BoxFlashing.hint: This section is only available when using HTTPS and a browser that supports the Web Serial API, such as Chrome or Edge. If you want to flash your ESP32 Toniebox, please click on "Proceed to HTTPS", and you will be automatically redirected to the HTTPS version. Your browser might warn that the connection is not secure. This is okay; confirm it and proceed to open the page anyway. You may need to display more details in the warning.
esp32BoxFlashing.hintLegacyApproach: If you prefer not to use a browser that supports WebSerial, you can still use the legacy method (no GUI, command line only).

legacy.checkDumpIsOk: Be sure, that the dump is okay and you are able to extract the certificates.
legacy.dnsIntro: You can either set the IP/hostname within the image or you may do it like described in the following.
legacy.flashCAreplacementText1: Replace the original CA within your flash dump with esptool.
legacy.flashCAreplacementText2: Reassamble your Toniebox again. If you already set the teddyCloud hostname, you can skip the DNS step for the ESP32, if not continue with DNS step for the ESP32.
legacy.flashCAreplacementText3: Your Toniebox should now be able to connect to your teddyCloud. Do a freshnesscheck and click on "Check available Boxes".
legacy.followLegacyApproach: Or use the legacy method (no GUI, command line only).
legacy.hint: There is a direct support of flashing your ESP32 Toniebox with TeddyCloud available!
legacy.installESPToolText: You can extract the flash memory via the debug port of the box and the esptool. Keep your backup! Please use a recent version of esptool. (>v4.4)
legacy.preparationText: Please connect your Toniebox to your Wi-Fi and update its firmware. Many boxes are shipped with a production firmware that needs to be updated. Otherwise the box won`t work as it should. It is not necessary to connect the box to the mytonies app/account.
legacy.preparationTextLink: Connect the box without the setup assistant.
legacy.skipDnsIfAlreadyDone: If you have already replaced the IP/hostname in the flash dump, you can skip this step here.
legacy.title: Legacy method of flashing

esp32BoxFlashing.linkWikiGeneral: Patching your Toniebox for using with TeddyCloud
esp32BoxFlashing.title: ESP32 Box Flashing

tonieboxes.hintLatestFirmware: For the initial setup with TeddyCloud of your Toniebox, please ensure it has the latest firmware installed. If you're unsure whether your Toniebox is up to date, connect it to the official cloud and allow some time for the firmware update to complete.

modelHint.action: to select the right model of your Toniebox

tonieboxes.newBoxesAllowedText: You can connect new Tonieboxes to TeddyCloud. Once you have connected all your boxes, please disable the "Allow new boxes" setting for security reasons.
tonieboxes.noDataText: Tonieboxes will only appear after establishing a successful connection. Ensure your Toniebox is connected properly.
tonieboxes.noNewBoxesAllowedText: You cannot connect new Tonieboxes to TeddyCloud. Please enable first the "Allow new boxes" setting. Once you have connected all your boxes, please disable the "Allow new boxes" setting for security reasons.
tonieboxes.title: Your Tonieboxes

tonies.noDataText: Tonies/Custom tags will only appear after a Toniebox has establishing a successful connection and already has Tonies/Custom tags on its SD card. Ensure your Toniebox is connected properly and has some Tonies/Custom tags on it or place your first Tonie/Custom tag on your Toniebox and refresh this site.

tapEditor.audioIdTooltip: Sets the audio id if the file is cached. Set it to 0 to force recreating the cached file
tapEditor.filePathContentFileTooltip: Sets the path to audio resource (must be compatible to ffmpeg)

tapEditor.filePathTooltip: Sets a path of TAF, which will be produced by ffmpeg

tonies.title: Tonies
